awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multi-Resolution Model and Context Aware Information Networking for Cooperative Vehicle Efficiency and Safety Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Every year around 30,000 fatalities and 2.2 million injuries happen on US roads. The problem is compounded with huge economic losses due to traffic congestions. Advances in Cooperative Vehicle Efficiency and Safety (CVES) systems promise to significantly reduce the human and economic cost of transportation. However, large scale deployment of such systems is impeded by significant technical and scientific gaps, especially when it comes to achieving real-time and high accuracy situational awareness for cooperating vehicles. This CAREER project aims at closing these gaps through developing fundamental information networking methodologies for coordinated control of automated systems. These methodologies will be based on the innovative concept of modeled knowledge propagation. In addition, the educational component of this project integrates interdisciplinary Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) subjects on the design of automated networked systems into graduate and undergraduate training modules. 

For robust operation, CVES systems require each vehicle to have reliable real-time awareness of the state of other coordinated vehicles. This project addresses the critical need for robust control-oriented situational awareness by developing a multi-resolution information networking methodology that is model- and context-aware. The approach is to develop the novel concepts of model communication and its derived multi-resolution networking. Context-aware model-communication relies on transmission and synchronization of models (e.g., stochastic hybrid system structures and parameters) instead of raw measurements. This allows for high fidelity synchronization of dynamical models of CVES over networks. Multi-resolution networking concept is enabled through scalable representations of models. Multi resolution models allow in-network adaptation of model fidelity to available network resources. The result is robustness of CVES to network service variability. 

The successful deployment of CVES, even partially, will provide significant societal benefits through reduced traffic accidents and improved efficiency. This project will enable large scale CVES deployment by addressing its scalability challenge. In addition, methodologies developed in this project will be crucial to emerging autonomous vehicles, which are also expected to coordinate their actions over communication networks. The fundamental research outcomes on knowledge propagation through network synchronization of dynamical models will be broadly applicable in other CPS domains such as smart grid. The educational component of this project will target training of CPS researchers and engineers on subjects in intelligent transportation and energy systems.

por.por_cntn:
Vehicle and transportation safety and efficiency are intrinsically important for the society. This project directly contributed to the development of technologies and methodologies for improved performance of connected or automated vehicles.

This project focused on designing learning-based information networking methods for connected and autonomous vehicles, to significantly improve their situational awareness and as a result the effectiveness of cooperative safety and efficiency systems. The project also included educational activities to broaden human resource development on cyber-physical system subjects.

The project produced the novel concept of model-communication; this concept transforms the information exchange paradigm from the traditional method of sharing measured data, to exchange of modeled and complex information constructs, without incurring additional communication load. This concept, along with new modeling schemes for description of driver and vehicle movement behavior, produced considerably more accurate methods for vehicle tracking in transportation safety systems. The improved effectiveness of vehicle safety systems, using the methods developed in this project, were also shown in a collaborative work with the automotive industry. Such efforts broadened the impact of the project beyond scientific discoveries, and into automotive industry applications.

Some of the specific technical outcomes of the project related to connected and automated vehicle applications include:

1-      Development of learning-based probabilistic methods for short-horizon vehicle tracking, halving the communication load on the network while maintaining or improving tracking accuracy. The load can be reduced up to 10 times compared to traditional 10Hz systems.

2-      Development of cooperative adaptive cruise control methods for vehicle platoons utilizing the learning-based models and communication, reducing spacing error between vehicles in a platoon by up to an order of magnitude compared to traditional methods.

3-      Development of neural network based methods for prediction of possible interference in a vehicle platoon and model-predictive reaction to the possible hazard, allowing 1-2 seconds of extra reaction time to pending cut-in hazards.

We have demonstrated that the concepts developed in this project can be used in other domains of science and technology by applying them to smart grid applications.  

Educational outcomes:

The scientific and industrial impacts of the project were broadened by its educational outcomes. The project involved mentoring of over 15 undergraduate and graduate students at different levels in this research. The project hired three undergraduate students from underrepresented groups at UCF. In addition, two new graduate courses on cyber-physical systems were designed with the help of this project: (1) EEE6712 Modeling and Analysis of Networked Cyber Physical Systems, (2) EEE5781 Cyber-Physical Technologies for Smart and Connected Communities. These courses have trained 50-60 students on the cyber-physical systems subjects related to intelligent transportation, industrial control, and energy systems. The senior design course at UCF has also benefited from the mentoring and resources of this project, which provided training opportunity for building a small-scale automated vehicle.

Technology transfer:

The project contributed to the development of several technologies for which patent applications and invention disclosures have been submitted. These include technologies for model-based vehicle tracking and connected vehicle safety systems, and cooperative object detection for connected or autonomous vehicle safety systems (patent application: PCT/US2021/037054). The latter is in the process of commercialization and has been licensed to a company.

 We have published and presented this interdisciplinary work in 18 scientific publications; lab demonstrations were also held for freshmen at UCF to encourage them to take up careers in engineering.

More information about the project is found on our website : https://cavrel.ece.ucf.edu/  and https://cavrel.ece.ucf.edu/index.php/projects/
